fields.descriptive_line:
Honoré Daumier. French School
Two men, one seated, and the other leaning against a mound.
fields.physical_description: A drawing of two elderly men talking, one seated, one leaning against a mound.  The gentleman on the left has a moustache and is wearing a black hat.
fields.title: Deux hommes
fields.location: Prints & Drawings Study Room, level C, case MB2D, shelf SH37, box IONIDES3
fields.marks:
recto: bottom left corner red ink collector's stamp: CAI surmounted by a crown.
verso: centre, black ink V&A stamp: V.A.M.

fields.location: Prints & Drawings Study Room, level C

fields.name: Prints & Drawings Study Room, level C

fields.public_access_description: Honoré Daumier (1808-79) was a  famous illustrator and satirist of  the nineteenth century known  for his anti-monarchist stance.   He was imprisoned for six  months in 1831 for the offence of  caricaturing King Louis-Philippe.   On the occassions where the  King censored the press Daumier  turned to everyday subjects and  bourgeois society for his  inspiration.  Here is a study of  two men in conversation, one sitting, one leaning on a mound.  The  vigorous line is typical of his work and the  simplicity of line is credit to his  fine observational skills and his humanity for  the subject.
fields.bibliography:
K.E. Maison, <u>Honoré Daumier, Catalogue Raisonné of the Paintings, Watercolours and Drawing</u>s, vol. II, <u>The Watercolours and Drawings</u>, London 1904, p.60, cat. no. 146, illus. plate 29.
E. Fuchs, <u>Der Maler Daumier</u>, Munich, 1927, cat. no. 225b.
Basil S. Long, <u>Catalogue of the Constantine Alexander Ionides Collection</u>, vol. I, <u>Paintings in Oil, </u><u>Tempera and Water-Colour together with certain of the Drawings</u>, London 1925, p. 17, cat. 126.
fields.historical_context_note: Honoré Daumier (1808-79), lithographer, painter and sculptor. This illustration of two men is typical of work created whilst censorship of the press was orderd by King Louis-Philippe. Daumier became increasingly interested with depicting everyday life. He is more famous, however, for his satirical work about the monarchy and the law courts and he first became familiar with the Palace of Justice at the age of just 13 where he worked as a bailiff's assistant. As a lithogrpaher, from the early 1830s, he drew on average 2 illustrations a week. Whilst working at one publication Le Charivari under Phillipon, he was imprisoned by King Louis-Philippe for his depiction of him as a Gargantua sitting on a commode. Phillipon, the printer Delaporte and the publisher Aubert were all imprisoned for their part in satirising the King. Censorship of the press was brought into force on several occassions, finally forcing Daumier to aim his satire at Bourgeois society instead and the recording of everyday life as seen in this study.
